| Hyperion dam = Traffic Court damsire = Discovery sex = Stallion foaled = 1952
| country = United States colour = Bay breeder = Philip Connors owner = 1)
| Clifford Mooers 2) Louis P. Doherty (12/1956) trainer = 1) Woody
| Stephens 2) James W. Maloney record = 44: 13-11-3 earnings = US$432,450
| race = Prairie State Stakes (1954) Withers Stakes (1955) Ohio Derby
| (1955) Ventnor Turf Handicap (1955) Jerome Handicap (1955) Woodward
| Stakes (1955) Laurel Turf Cup Handicap (1956) Metropolitan Handicap
| (1957) Suburban Handicap (1957) awards = honours = updated=
}} 'Traffic Judge' (1952-1972) was an American Thoroughbred racehorse. He was
owned by Clifford Mooers, proprietor of Walnut Springs Farm in Lexington,
Kentucky, and trained by future U.S. Racing Hall of Fame inductee, Woody
Stephens. On November 13, 1956 Clifford Mooers died of a heart attack at New
York City's LaGuardia Airport while en route to see Traffic Judge compete in the
Narragansett Special. [http://news.google.ca/newspapers?id=qa0yAAAAIBAJ&sji-
d=CuwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4262,5262252&dq=clifford-mooers&hl=en Miami News - November
14, 1956] His estate auctioned the horse and on December 24 he was
purchased for $362,345.70 by Louis P. Doherty, owner of The Stallion Station on
Muir Station Road in Lexington, Kentucky. [http://select.nytimes.com/gst/ab-
stract.html?res=FB0A13F73455177B93C7AB1789D95F428585F9 New York Times â December
25, 1956] Traffic Judge's race conditioning was then taken over by another
Hall of Fame inductee, James W. Maloney.

Traffic Judge showed some promise at age two when he won the 1954 Prairie State
Stakes at Washington Park Race Track in Chicago. [http://select.nytimes.com-
/gst/abstract.html?res=F00611FB3A5A107B93CBA81783D85F408585F9 New York Times â
August 19, 1954] In the 1955 U.S. Triple Crown series, Traffic Judge did
not run in the Kentucky Derby or Belmont Stakes but did compete in the Preakness
Stakes and finished third to winner Nashua. [http://news.google.ca/newspape-
rs?id=erwyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5uoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1576,4325748&dq=traffic+judge+preakness-
&hl=en Miami News â May 29, 1955] Traffic Judge did however win several
important races that year including the Ohio Derby [http://news.google.ca/-
newspapers?id=AwcrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TpgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6944,3679661&dq=traffic+judge+o-
hio+derby&hl=en Reading Eagle â June 26, 1955] the Ventnor Turf Handicap
[http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10B11F93A5D13728DDDAD089-
4D1405B8589F1D3 New York Times â September 4, 1955] and the Jerome
Handicap [http://news.google.ca/newspapers?id=BwYuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=N4AFAAAAIB-
AJ&pg=3106,4026950&dq=traffic+judge+jerome+handicap&hl=en Modesto Bee â
September 30, 1955] for three year olds as well as the Woodward Stakes, a
major weight-for-age race against older horses. [http://select.nytimes.com/-
gst/abstract.html?res=FA0E13FE3A5E127A93C0A9178BD95F418585F9 New York Times â
October 2, 1955]

Traffic Judge won the Laurel Turf Cup Handicap at age four and at age five won
two major races for older horses, the Metropolitan and Suburban Handicaps.

Retired to stud, Traffic Judge was the sire of Traffic, the 1963 Hopeful Stakes
winner in the United States who went on to stand at stud in France where he was
the 1971 Leading sire. Other of Traffic Judge's progeny who were successful in
racing included multiple stakes winners Green Ticket (1959), Traffic Mark
(1966), Judgeable (1969) and Grade 1 winner Court Ruling (1970). In addition, he
sired Best In Show (1965) who was voted Kentucky Broodmare of the Year in 1982.

Traffic Judge died at age twenty in 1972 and was buried at The Stallion Station
now known as 505 Farm. [http://www.tbheritage.com/TurfHallmarks/Graves/Grav-
eMattersFarmNAM.html Grave Matters, Thoroughbred Heritage]
categories: Racehorses bred in the United States
